name: Hidden Treasures: 6 Museums Off the Beaten Track

text.text: Hidden Treasures: 6 Museums Off the Beaten Track

Did you know that London has a lot of museums? Sure you did, sure. There are plenty of prestigious, tourist-ridden institutions that tell big tales about the History of the World; but we like ourselves the lesser-known, off-the-beaten-track museums that feel like undiscovered gems when stumbled upon. Places that draw us into a whole new world for an hour but don't require us to passive-aggressively shoulder barge a group of Italian school children out the way. Come with us on a micro-adventure of learning.

tip.text:
There might be museums with more hype, followers and tourist footfall, but it's the small museums of London that are its real treasures and this is a classic example. Here we have one of the greatest collections of Egyptian and Sudanese archaeology in the world, a crazy horde of some 80,000 objects mainly put together by Sir Flinders Petrie, the original bossman of modern archaeology.

Part of the UCL campus, it's not the largest place but it packs plenty in, spanning life in the Nile Valley from prehistory to the time of the pharaohs, the Romans, the Coptics and even the Islamic period. Yep, Egypt has seen plenty of action - if it was a TV series it would take weeks to get through the entire box set.

All the objects here were taken from documented excavations, with the collection including one of the earliest pieces of linen from Egypt; the earliest example of metal from Egypt; and the oldest wills on papyrus paper. Along with outstanding works of art, colourful tiles, carvings and frescoes and mummy portraits, you have yourself some real, bona fide history.

text.text:

With outstanding works of art, colourful tiles, carvings and frescoes and mummy portraits, you have yourself some real, bona fide history.

tip.text:
On a quiet street in Kennington you'll find this enchanting treasure trove of all things cinema - a well curated archive that should satisfy the buffest of film buff's cravings. Formerly the workhouse of a young Charlie Chaplin, this place is largely about the social function that cinema has played over time - a journey through time involving carpets, cigarette trays, screens, posters, projectors, usher uniforms, photography and, of course, film. It's a loving ode to the grandeur and history of the cinema from people who clearly give a shit about it.

In an interesting little quirk, you can only visit this place with a guided tour. Maybe they don't trust you not to steal, or question whether you'll really be able to understand what's going on. Either way, contact them to organise. Entry is £10. Also, their lease is up in March, at which point the landlords will inevitably sell it to the highest bidder, so if you want to get involved with saving this place, check their website for details.

tip.text:
Founded in 1247, Bethlem psychiatric hospital has quite the chequered history. Back in Victorian times, people used to pay and come and look at 'the crazies' as some kind of fucked up hobby. Times, and the hospital's location, have changed since then and there's now a small museum here that tackles the subject of mental health, and the hospital's past, head on and in fascinating detail.

In an Art Deco old hospital administration building, this is a collection centred around the de-stigmatisation of mental health. Along with an art gallery showing the works of several renowned artists who spent time in Bethlem, there's also plenty of historical objects such as the leather and iron shackles used to strap patients down. It's an excellent resource for seeing the history of mental healthcare and its treatment. It doesn't shy away from the shit that's gone before and is definitely worth an hour of your time.

Open on the first and last Saturday of the month.

tip.text:
We’ll never tire of seeing weird-looking specimens in jars (as a quick browse of our fridge will attest). The Darwin Centre, part of the Natural History Museum, is a world-class scientific centre for research, learning, analysis and simply having a wide-eyed browse. A fairly recent extension to the NHM, it's an amazing structure in itself: eight stories high and shaped like a cocoon, packed full of biological specimens from this strange thing we like to call 'existence'.

Split into a couple of sections, the Darwin Cocoon is home to hundreds of things with beetles, butterflies, herbaria and all kinds of plants - this is where scientists are actually working, extracting, processing, sequencing and analysing the DNA of plants and insects. The Zoology Spirit section, meanwhile, is home to the larger animals in jars, housing some of the first species ever recorded by anyone. You'll spot the iconic giant squid, Komodo dragons and smaller animals we're not even capable of imagining.

Whilst entry is free, the best way to see some of that rare, secret stuff they lock away is through a tour which are very highly rated.

listing.name: Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising
listing.subtitle: Evolution of Consumer Culture

tip.text:
Advertising is so hard to ignore these days, we sometimes scrutinise Whatsapp messages from our mum to double-check she isn't trying to sell us something. Well guess what, advertising isn't new, and this museum is an exploration of the history of consumer culture. Taking things back to the 1800s, this is a showcase of around 12,000 items travelling from the naive charm of the Victorian era to the sophisticated shittery of today.

We're talking Rimmel cosmetics from the 1890s, First World War Oxo Cubes, Mars Bars, Rolos and KitKats from the 1930s and a 1970s Chopper bike. It's a poignant reflection on the evolution of shopping patterns and human nature. Plus, check out their south-facing courtyard garden which is a laaavly spot for a sit.

Entry is £9

tip.text: It might be small and cosy but boy have they packed a lot of specimens into this place: a macabre, captivating window into the animal kingdom. London's last remaining zoological museum, it has 68,000 specimens in its locker, although only 7% of those are on display - but fear not, it's the good stuff (we're promised). Anything that's ever called itself an animal has a place here, with mounted creatures, strange specimens in fluid and skeletons galore. It's free entry and a reliable shout for a curious hour.
